text: Welcome to exploring computing.

Today's video is computer
security introduction.

So I want to start off by
talking about some stories,
about some security problems.

And I'll admit these
are a little bit scary.

We will be talking about
how to protect your computer
in a couple lectures.

So you can keep that
in mind when you're
listening to these stories.

All right, so our first story
has to do with the Dalai Lama

and a attack using a
network called the GhostNet.

In 2009 the Dalai Lama's
computers were infected

and a program called
the GhOst RAT--

where RAT stands for
remote access tools--

was installed on the
computers in his offices.

The RAT tools gave remote
access, including access

to files on the computer--
being able to transfer them

off the computer to
elsewhere on the internet,

gave complete control over
the microphones and cameras.

And ultimately,
GhOst RAT ended up

infecting over 1,200 computers
in over 100 countries.

Most of the computers were in
foreign affairs ministries,

embassies and non-governmental
organizations.

The attack vector that was
used to install these programs

on the Dalai Lama's
computers, was

a email from an email address
marked, campaign@freetibet.org.

There was a Word
document attached

to the email,
entitled, "Translation

of freedom of movement for
Tibetans in exile dot doc."

Well, we don't
have 100% certainty

who attacked the Dalai
Lama's computers.

One year investigation by
Canadian security experts,

tracked where the GhOst RAT
was sending information back

to Hainan Island in China, which
is the home of Chinese Signals
Intelligence Unit.

So it's likely, given who might
want to hack the Dalai Lama,

and given what they
were able to discover

about how the tools work,
it was probably China.
All right, here's another story.

In 2010, the FBI
monitoring software

detected anomalies from
the NASDAQ Stock Exchange
computers.

When they went in,
they discovered

that there was software
installed on the computers,
that included destructive code.

They weren't able
to 100% discern what

the destructive code
was supposed to do,

but it included two
day-zero exploits.

And this is a subject
that's going to come up
in a bunch of other places.

A day-zero exploit,
is an exploit
that nobody has seen before.

So this is something
that somebody has found

is a vulnerability
in existing software,
and nobody knows about it.

So if you have a
day-zero exploit,

generally, that's considered
a pretty huge deal,

and you're going to want to
keep that in your back pocket,

and only use it when you
really, really need to.

Because basically, it's kind
of like the coronavirus, where

there's a whole
wide field out there

and nobody has any
defenses against it.

So to give you an example
of the opposite of that,

we'll be talking in more detail
about this particular example
later in this lecture series.

But there was a
ransomware attack

that happened a couple of years
ago, that among other things

took out the British
National Health computers.
That was not a day-zero exploit.

If anybody had updated
their Windows computers,

they were not vulnerable
to that virus.
So this was a known issue.
Again, not a day-zero exploit.

A day-zero exploit is something
where nobody's seen it before,

and it's pretty much guaranteed
to work on any computer
that you use it on.

So in this particular
case, there

were two day-zero
exploits used in order
to get to the NASDAQ computers.

The signature on the software
that was used to attack NASDAQ
matched Russian FSB.

Russian FSB is the
successor to the KGB, and--

well, it's half of the
successor to the KGB.

There's another
successor agency as well,

and it's basically roughly
equivalent to the US FBI.

You can hear Maddie
in the background,

she really wants me
to play with her.

So it's likely that
this came from the FSB

but it's also
possible that somebody
stole the code from the FSB.

It also turns out
that, for example,

code that the NSA uses to
attack computers at one point

was stolen, or was misplaced and
ended up out on the internet.

So it is possible
that this wasn't
the FSB using their code.

It's possible somebody
else was using their code.

Ultimately, we don't know
who attacked the NASDAQ.

Some people point
the finger at China,
but it's most likely Russia.

At around the time
that hack occurred,

Russia was working on the
Russian Stock Exchange,

so it's possible that
the people hacking

the NASDAQ were actually
looking for techniques,

and the internal
workings of the computers

to use for the Russian
Stock Exchange.

However, in addition
to the original attack,

the FBI found other pieces
of software also installed
on NASDAQ.
This is kind of scary.

They found signs of various
groups operating on the NASDAQ

computers, including criminal
hackers and Chinese cyberspies.

They also discovered that the
One Liberty Plaza building

management-- that's where
the NASDAQ is located.

Their website had been infested
with a Blackhole exploit

kit, which basically anybody who
visited their website, if they

were trying to pay their bills
or doing other maintenance,
they would get infected.

In May 5, 2000, an email
titled ILOVEYOU was sent out.

And it included a virus, and
it was designed as a worm

to distribute itself
across the internet.

Ultimately, 45 million
computers were infected.

It used a Visual
Basic Script file,

which copied itself to other
Visual Basic Script files.

It sent out copies of itself to
everyone in the Outlook email
address book.

So if you were using Outlook,
it would look through your email

addresses and it would
just basically create

duplicate copies
then mail message.

And that would affect
everybody in your mail book.

It overwrote multimedia
files, including JPEGs.

It sent copies of itself
to people on chat rooms,

and it contacted four
websites in the Philippines.

The perpetrators were
identified, but at the time

no computer crime laws
existed in the Philippines,

so they were
ultimately not charged.

In 2016, John Podesta, who was
chairman of Hillary Clinton's

2016 presidential campaign,
received an email claiming
to be a Google security alert.

He clicked on the link,
and entered his password
information.
And of course, it wasn't Google.

And Wikileaks published
over 20,000 pages

of Clinton campaign
emails, by getting in

through his original
email access.

Security experts
believe the hack

was done by hacking group
called Fancy Bear, which

is associated with the
Russian Intelligence Services.

Stuxnet is a program
that was designed
to attack Siemen's equipment.

Ultimately, the
target was believed

to be Iran's nuclear
program, which
was using Siemens equipment.

And in particular, it was
going after their centrifuges.

It was basically throwing off
the timing on the centrifuges,

and it was designed to
destroy the centrifuges being
used to refine uranium.

Stuxnet was designed to spread
itself through a network.

It replicated itself
through Windows computers,

and looked for Siemens
Windows-based software,

where it attacked programmable
logic controllers.

It included four
day-zero exploits--

remember we talked about
day-zero exploits--

which led everybody
to believe that it

was being put out by a nation
states, national security
apparatus.

There was a
vulnerability it used
to spread across USB sticks.

This is believed
to be necessary,

because the Iranian nuclear
enrichment facilities were
probably not on the internet.

So somehow, you would
have to get the virus
into their internal network.

And so, this is likely
done through a USB drive.

Possibly, by actually having
your agent there in place.

We'll talk about some other
methods in the next lecture,

in terms of how you
might get somebody

to stick a USB drive
onto their computer.
Turns out it's not very hard.

It used a vulnerability
in print spoolers

to spread across networks
using shared printers,

and it used two
different vulnerabilities

to gain proper
privileged access,

once it got on a
particular computer.

All right, so we're going to
have three different lectures
on security.

The rest of today's
lecture is going

to focus on mechanisms
for security--

Different ways that
computer scientists
protect your computers.

The next lecture is going
to focus on different ways

your computer can get
attacked, and then

the third lecture will
focus on how to defend
your computer from attacks.

For today's lecture, I
want to focus on four
different security concerns--

confidentiality, authentication,
integrity, and non-repudiation.

Confidentiality has
to do with-- when

I'm talking to
somebody else, how

do I know that somebody
else isn't listening in?
So I'm going to use--

for most of these
examples, I'm going
to use Alice, Bob, and Mallory.

These are traditional names
used by security researchers,

so if your name's
Mallory, I'm sorry.

It's not my fault.
And there's actually

over 20 different names
of different people

in different roles,
but I'm just going

to use Alice and Bob, who are
just two people that are trying

to communicate
over the internet,

and then Mallory
is the attacker.

There's all sorts of different
variants, where like,

Eve is there to
eavesdrop, Mallory
is there to do malicious things.

And as I said, there's
over 20 different names,

but we're just going to use
Alice, Bob, and Mallory,
for most of the examples.

So Alice is sending a message
to Bob, she says, hey,
do you want to meet for lunch?

And confidentiality, means
that only Alice and Bob
can read that message.

If a third party like
Mallory is able to read it,

that means we don't
have confidentiality.

Authentication means
that the person

we're communicating
with, actually
is who they say they are.

So in this case,
Alice is communicating

over the internet, and she
thinks she's talking to Bob,

but how do we know
she's talking to Bob?
Maybe she's talking to Mallory.

And so authentication,
is how can Bob
prove that Bob really is Bob?

How can Alice be sure
that that's Bob over there
and not Mallory.
Integrity has to do with--

can somebody
manipulate the message?

So you might be
able to manipulate

the message, or
corrupt the message,

without actually being
able to read the message.

So this is interrelated
with confidentiality

and authentication, but there's
different variants here,

in terms of what a
malicious person could do.

That don't necessarily
violate confidentiality,

or don't necessarily
violate authentication.

All right, so Alice
sent this message

to meet for lunch to
Bob, and maybe Mallory

is not able to actually
change the message,

but he's able to add
on to the message.

So he says, meet for lunch at
Coho, and Bob goes to Coho,

and Alice is somewhere
else and doesn't
know why Bob didn't show up.

Another possibility
is Mallory might

be able to actually see
the message being sent,

grab the message, and
then send the same message
at a later point in time.

And Bob might not realize
that he's actually

seeing a message that's
been seen previously.

So if the system's
not set up properly,

he'll know that it was sent
from Alice, because maybe there

is some security
credentials on it,

but if Mallory is able to grab
the whole thing, including

the security credentials and
just resend at a later date,

Bob's going to think he's
supposed to meet for lunch,

and Alice won't be there
because this is actually

a repeat from a message that
was sent a couple of days ago.
All right, non-repudiation.

So suppose I send
out an email that
says there's no final exam.

And usually, there's a
point in the quarter where

I make a joke about, but
there really is a final exam.

So I'm not saying this
is not a real example,

but hey, turns out this
quarter, there is no final exam.
So yay.

All right, so suppose I send an
email that says, no final exam,
and you guys all get it.

And then I claim, I
didn't send it out.

Is there a way that you can
prove I actually sent it?

And so that's what
non-repudiation has to do with.

OK, so this is just
a quick reminder

that this lecture was
originally recorded last spring,

and that in fact, we do
have a final this quarter.
But it will be open-book--
open-note.

And it should be
pretty easy for you.

You will have plenty
of time for it.
Very low pressure.

All right, back to your
prerecorded lecture.

All right, so in the
next video, we're

going to talk about
different mechanisms

that we use for
computer security,

and how they might be used
to address these four issues.
I'll talk to you soon.
